sec.title: Overview of primary sources of privacy protection principles (PPP)

p.italic: Since the development of the 1st edition of our JTC1/SC36 standard and the publication of its 1st edition in 2013, there have been changes to the three primary sources noted referenced in Clause 5.1. On the whole they have not required changes to the 11 fundamental Privacy protection Principles (PPR) already identified In Clause 5.3.
However, the text in Clause 5.1, its footnotes, as well as its Figures H.2 has been updated to reflect the changes in the references to these three-primary sources,

It is noted that these changes to the current/new editions of the OECD Guidelines, that of the EU Directives to the EU GDPR as well as that of the APEC Privacy Framework have not required a change to the 11 Privacy Protection Principles already identified in the 1st edition of our ISO/IEC 29187-1 standard.

On the contrary, changes in the EU for its “Directives” to it new (and now enforce GDPR) not only support our JTC1/SC36 ISO/IEC 29187-1 standards development work and our resulting 1st edition standard,

In addition, a key aspect of the EU GDPR is that is not only fully support the 11 PPRs in our ISO/IEC 29187-1 standard but also adds (the thitherto missing) new mandatory compliance requirements along with punitive measures financial, as well as other non-financial penalties relating to the same for non-compliance
In addition, the new EU “GDPR” adds new privacy protection requirements (PPR) including those of An enforcement nature

sec.p: Whilst there is acknowledgement that information must, of necessity, be exchanged in the furtherance of the goals and actualization of a learning transaction, many jurisdictional domains require that where personal information is concerned particular external constraints apply, i.e., those which involve an individual learner as a party to a learning transaction.

Although legislation and regulations of a privacy/data protection nature differ among the many jurisdictional domains where they exist, on the whole, there are many “generic” elements. A high-level review and analysis of privacy/data protection legislation in Australia, Canada, Japan, USA, (and APEC member states), the EU, and Norway as well as Europe (both at the EU level, and that of component countries (and within country such as those of Länder within Germany, provinces/territories in Canada, etc.), indicates that all these laws and regulations have common primitive requirements. These are captured and integrated below into a single set of common privacy protection principles.

The essential aspects of each of these eleven (11) common privacy protection principles and their requirements are captured below along with associates of rules.
The development of the Part 1 of the multipart ISO/IEC 29187 set of privacy protection and LET standard standards focuses on common primitives which are captured in the form of principles and their rules along with clearly defined concepts, i.e., as a rule-based approach in support of the Learning Operational View (LOV). It is noted that for LET providers and public administrations to be able to comply with these rules as external constraints, which apply to them, they have to ensure that their surrounding and overarching learning processes and IT systems may be required to be changed to be able to support external constraints of this nature.
The three most common and international recognized and accepted sources for privacy protection requirements are:

list-item.p:
The 2013 OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data / Lignes directrices de l'OCDE sur la protection de la vie privée et les flux transfrontières de données de caractère personnel.
The 2013 revision of the OECD Guidelines constitutes the first update of the original 1980 version that served as the first internationally agreed upon set of privacy principles. The 2013 revision leaves intact the original “Basic Principles” of the Guidelines which remain valid. See further https://www.oecd.org/sti/ieconomy/privacy-guidelines.htm . This URL also provides a link to a very useful 154 page OECD publication titled “The OECD Privacy Framework”

The 2016 EU General Data Protection Directive (GDPR)
The EU GDPR refers to the Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC. For the text of the GDPR and related documents and information see further https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2016/679/oj . It provides the text for the GDPR in the official languages of all the EU member states. on the on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data.

the 2017 APEC Privacy Framework
The APEC Privacy Framework is a set of principles and implementation guidelines that were created in order to establish effective privacy protections that avoid barriers to information flows, and ensure continued trade and economic growth in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation region of 27 countries. The Framework, which aims at promoting electronic commerce throughout the Asia Pacific region, is consistent with the core values of the OECD’s Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Trans-Border Flows of Personal Data (OECD Guidelines), and reaffirms the value of privacy to individuals and to the information society.
The previous version of the Framework (2005) was modelled upon the OECD Guidelines (1980) which at that time represented the international consensus on what constitutes fair and trustworthy treatment of personal information. The updated Framework (2015) draws upon concepts introduced into the OECD Guidelines (2013) with due consideration for the different legal features and context of the APEC region. [See further, https://www.apec.org/Publications/2017/08/APEC-Privacy-Framework-(2015) ]

sec.p: These three normative references, i.e., as referenced specifications are indispensable to the understanding and use of this document. In addition, the following three normative references are also essential to the understanding and use of this this contribution:

list-item.p:
the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD)
All of the ISO/IEC JTC1 P-members are signatories to this UN Convention which thus applies to them as another set of “top-down” legal/regulatory requirements as rights of an individual. [See further https://www.un.org/development/desa/disabilities/convention-on-the-rights-of-persons-with-disabilities.html . Here also of particular relevance here is the ISO/IEC standard developed by its ISO/IEC JTC1/SC36 ITLET titled “ISO/IEC 20016-1: ITLET – Language Accessibility and Human Interface Equivalencies (HIEs) in e-Learning Applications – Part 1: Framework and Reference Model for Interoperability / ISO/CEI 20016-1: Accessibilité linguistique et équivalences d'interface humaine (ÉIH) dans les applications d'e-apprentissage – Partie 1: Cadre et modèle de référence pour interopérabilité sémantique.[See further https://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ ]; and,

the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties.
The basic rules for the formation and identification of jurisdictional domains are governed by the Charter of the United Nations and more specifically by the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties. The Vienna Convention also governs the formation and recognition of internationally recognized treaties, conventions, etc. [See further https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-d&q=vienna+convention+on+the+law+of+treaties
As to how the Vienna Convention is important and relevant in a LOV context see Clause 7.Rules governing the formation and identification of jurisdictional domains” in ISO/IEC 15944-5 Information technology – Business Operational View – Part 5: Identification and referencing of requirements of jurisdictional as sources of external constraints”. [See further https://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ ].

sec.p: The approach to the development of the 11 principles governing privacy protection requirements based on these primary sources of requirements is illustrated in the following .
Exceptions to the application of the privacy protection principles

Privacy protection requirements of jurisdictional domains may contain exceptions (derogations) to the application of external constraints of this nature. The most common exceptions are those relating to national sovereignty and security, law enforcement, public safety and health. Exceptions of this nature often requires access to personal information about a particular individual learner and the tracing of any other personal information pertaining to that individual learner
Traceability issues including those pertaining to individuals in any type of a “commitment exchange” nature, including business transactions, learning transaction, etc. are addressed in ISO/IEC 15944-9 “information technology – Business Operational View (BOV) – Part 9: Traceability Framework.[See further https://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ ] (e.g., access to personal information by particular Persons other than those who are parties to the learning transaction, i.e., qualified and specified public administrations based on predefined criteria).

p.bold: Where exceptions to the application of privacy protection principles exist, they shall be:

limited and proportional
In relation to “limited and proportional”, the APEC Privacy Framework, Clause 13 states that “The Principles contained in Part III of the APEC Privacy Framework should be interpreted as a whole rather than individually, as there is a close relationship among them”. It goes on to state that countries implementing the Framework “may adopt suitable exceptions that suit their particular circumstances”. Further, “one should take into consideration the impact of these activities”, i.e., invocation of an exception, “upon the rights, responsibilities and legitimate interests of individuals”. to meeting the objectives to which these exceptions relate; and,
